page.title: 12BAGWORTH PIT
page.content: Bagworth Colliery dates back to 1825 when it was owned by Lord Maynard. It is one of the oldest coalmines still in production in the South Midlands area.Coalmining developed after the building of the Swannington and Leicester Railway in 1832 by Robert Stevenson.Coal could be delivered to the City of Leicester for less than 50p per ton.Bagworth Colliery is situated at the southern end of Leicestershire Coalfield bordered by the Thringstone Fault which divides our area.Working conditions are relatively easy.There being no gas or heat and the fault pattern is not excessive.The seams are all poor quality.Coal is mainly for the electricity and industrial markets. Bagworth Colliery employs 820 men of whom 660 work underground and 3,540 men work on the coalface each day.
